sections.title: Introduction
sections.content: Welcome to Units 29 and 30 of our English learning journey. In these units, we'll explore the use of 'may' and 'might'

sections.title: Definition
sections.content: to express possibility, probability, and permission. Let's delve into the key concepts.

sections.title: 'May' and 'light' for Possibility
sections.content: Use 'may' and 'might' to express the possibility of an event occurring.
points: It may rain later; bring an umbrella
She might come to the party if she finishes work on time

sections.title: 'May' and 'Might' for Permission
sections.content: Use 'may' to express formal permission, and 'might' for a more tentative or polite expression
points: You may leave the room now
Might I borrow your pen for a moment?

sections.title: Examples
sections.content: Let's examine examples to illustrate the application of 'may' and 'might'
points: She may join us for dinner later.
You may use my laptop if yours isn't working
It might snow tomorrow, so be prepared

sections.title: Common Mistakes
sections.content: Address common mistakes related to the interchangeable use of 'may' and 'might' and distinguish their roles in expressing possibility and permission

sections.title: Recap and Summary:
sections.content: In summary, 'may' and 'might' are versatile in expressing possibility and permission. Pay attention to the specific contexts in which each is used.

sections.title: Additional Resources:
sections.content: For additional practice and reinforcement, consider exploring examples in language learning books and online exercises.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Thank you for joining today's lesson on 'May and Might' Practice using these expressions confidently in various situations, and feel free to reach out if you have any questions. Happy learning!
